awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Tool for In-situ Stress Measurement in Deep Downhole Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to improve safety and economics of subsurface operations, such as drilling, stimulation, production, and injection, associated with geological carbon sequestration and production of geothermal heat and fossil fuels from subsurface rock formations. These operations can affect personnel safety, loss of capital, significant damage to the environment, and increase emission of greenhouse gases. To optimize subsurface operations, knowledge of the state of stress in rock formations is essential. Failure to construct reasonably accurate stress models costs the oil and gas industry several billions of dollars annually. However, determination of in-situ stresses is one of the major challenges in the subsurface engineering and currently no technology directly measures these stressees in deep formations. This project advances a tool to measure these stresses directly.
 
This SBIR Phase I project proposes to design and develop a robust an innovative downhole tool for direct measurement of all stress components and the stress orientation in deep wells with any well trajectories. The objectives of the Phase I research study include: 1) Develop analytical and numerical solutions to accurately obtain far-field stresses from near-wellbore stresses.  2) Design and render the tool and all its components for borehole sizes range 7” to 12 ¼”.  3) Develop numerical modeling and simulation of different downhole conditions.  4) Design the mechanical, hydraulic, and electrical components, materials, and sensors/transducers and preparation for prototyping.  The proposed tool has a novel modular design for wireline, drill-pipe and coil tubing applicable to vertical, deviated, and horizontal wells. This measurement can be repeated as needed to determine the full stress tensor. The technology is automatically operated from the surface. The exact position and orientation of the tool is determined by an assembly and magnetometer, respectively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Despite the development of advanced analytical and numerical modeling and the considerable amount of capital spent on the development of analytical and numerical models to estimate in-situ stresses in 1D and 3D, the importance of calibration of these models with actual measurements of field stresses has been overlooked. The in-situ stresses are notoriously difficult to estimate, and their estimation without calibration to reliable measurements can be extremely misleading. As of today, there is no technology available to directly measure all stress components in deep formations. All the available techniques provide indirect estimates by measuring other parameters (mainly deformation and pressure response). Normally, there are large uncertainties in stress predictions since these techniques rely on oversimplified evaluations and unrealistic assumptions. In view of these limitations and considering the current requirements for improving subsurface operations and monitoring capabilities, there is a justified need for developing new technologies for direct stress measurement in deep formations. In this SBIR Phase I project, Teverra designed an innovative downhole tool that is able to directly measure stresses in different locations and orientation within a borehole (so called DFISS). DFISS applies a proven concept to measure stresses in different locations and orientations in harsh deep downhole conditions. DFISS operates in a limited space in different well trajectories under varying downhole conditions.

DFISS provides a novel solution to a major challenge associated with almost all subsurface operations. It will have a huge impact in improving the accuracy and reliability of geomechanical models used for drilling, completions, stimulation, injection, and production optimization, in conventional and unconventional oil and gas, carbon storage, and geothermal applications. Unreliable knowledge of in-situ stresses costs energy industry billions of dollars every year. These losses are associated with non-productive time during drilling caused by stress-related problems; poor well design (i.e., trajectory, casing, and mud designs); failure of hydraulic fracturing treatments; erroneous prediction of fracture dimensions and direction; poor evaluation of conductivity of induced and natural fractures; flawed placement of parent and child wells; well integrity issues, unpredicted induced seismicity, and lack of understanding of the production during life of the reservoir. The specific benefit of this technology in the context of fracture diagnostics is its ability to make several measurements along the horizontal sections in unconventional rocks, where there are typically limited data/logs available, and map the magnitude and orientation of near-wellbore and far-field stresses along the lateral. Thus, the tool after commercialization has potential to disrupt the subsurface characterization market. Due to the current need for drilling longer wells and producing from deeper formations and considering the importance of in-situ stresses in nearly all related operations, it is expected that the developed technology will rapidly gain extensive popularity among service providers and operating companies in geothermal, subsurface energy storage, carbon storage, and oil and gas applications, onshore and offshore.


Last Modified: 10/08/2023
Modified by: Hamed Soroush
